item.description:
In the complex web of key players pushing the frontiers of human knowledge, I am positioned at the interface of three thematic vertices 1. Experimental Science 2. High-throughput Technology and 3. Informatics. My academic interests span a wide range of natural science questions, with the point of convergence being the development and application of computational methods - from data processing to exploratory visualization to modeling.

At Institute for Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research, two research areas of interest were 1. elucidating transcript, protein and metabolite level changes accompanying root senescence and 2. identification of gene expression patterns in nutrient perturbed crop plants.

At Leibniz Lung Center, I developed methods for error modeling mass spectrometry data and conceptualized a novel metric for determining lipidome homology. Prior to that, at the National Center for Biological Sciences, I applied sequence alignment algorithms for small molecule structure comparison and developed a stochastic model of Transcription. At the Center for Cellular and Molecular Biology, the focus was to reconstruct microbial metabolic pathways from publicly available databases and analyze the network topology.

Away from work, I enjoy bicyling, running and reading. Favorite book is To Kill a Mocking Bird by Harper Lee. Favorite running event is Troms√∏ Polar Night Halfmarathon.
